description:
A variant form of chess played with the usual pieces on an infinity-symbol-shaped board. While the rules are nearly identical to those of standard chess, the differing topology changes the game substantially.

Original websites for it are no longer up, but the WayBack Machine has a cached version at https://web.archive.org/web/20141017211751/http://www.colebank.com:80/ichess/index.asp

Ísland - spurningaspil (Iceland) is basically a trivia game with some economic traits, where you travel around Iceland and along the way you can buy and sell properties and build motels and hotels on those properties. Other players pay rent when they land on a property belonging to others.

If you land on a question spot, you have ten seconds to answer the question (six categories), getting a reward if answered correctly, or paying a penalty (money or doing something silly) if getting the answer wrong. Players decide for how long they play, whether for a set period of time or as long it takes to eliminate all the others.

The exciting race game where players pieces may suddenly disappear with a "plonk".

The game board consists of two layers. The top layer has a race course with hole on each square surrounded by a plastic rim to hold upright the narrow player pawns. The bottom layer is on black card with various holes and sits inside the box. When the upper board is placed on top most squares on the race track have a solid footing for the pawns, but some have holes that allow the pawns to fall through into the box and out of the game. The boards are square so that they can be rotated in relation to each other to provide variable distribution of the holes.

Each player takes 5 pawns. The winner is the first person to get a pawn to the end of the track. Players roll the dice and move one of their pawns the distance indicated. If they have multiple pawns on the track they can chose which one to move. When a hole is discovered by a player losing their piece to it all players need to remember where it is so that they don't repeat the mistake.
Pictured in Games We Play, the players move their trucks around the board to the variable fire locations.
Roll-and-move game featuring train travel in Europe.  Pictured in Games We Play.

This is an odd version of roulette.  A British plane which is on a counter-weighted arm is "flown" in a circle over the playing surface.  Players wager on where the plane will land.  Payoffs are made based on the size of the area.

A reworking of classic games of flying around the world, but instead players just move around Germany.  It came out at a time when German planes really couldn't go anywhere with a peaceful landing in mind.

Pictured in the book Games We Play.

From the publisher:
A novel game with Goblins.  The figures are made to jump into the perforated board with a 5x5 grid.

Pictured in the book Games We Play, from the illustration, one can't figure out if the point is to get the correct hole in the board or avoid the holes in the board.

Pictured in the book Games We Play, this is a roll and move game played on two stars, one on the inside of each half of a box.  It appears that players collect the tokens put out on each point of the star at the start of the game.

Featured in the book Games We Play as an example of an early lithograph game published in Nuremberg, from the illustration it appears to be an early version of Tangoes, with red and blue geometric shapes that can be arranged to create "flowers."

A wargame depicting the Battle of Talana Hill -- October 20, 1899.

A deck of playing cards determines who does what and when (if a red card is drawn, the British player activates one counter. If it is a black card, the Boer player activates one counter.)

Players win by obtaining more victory points than their opponent. Victory points are obtained for inflicting casualties.

Very little is known about the game.  The box describes it as "A Game of Warring Nations".   The pieces are colored wooden pieces with flags of five countries attached (England, France, Germany, Austria Hungary, Russia).  The game play is point to point with captures happening when there is no place to retreat to and controlled capitals are used to determine winners at the end of the game.

Players roll dice to determine which colored pieces they can activate. When activated, a player can do the following with the piece:

* Place a small piece onto your home row under your control.
  * Upgrade a piece you control or one that is standing.
  * Move a piece you control
  * Activate a lying piece you control by standing it up.
  * Activate a standing piece by downgrading it. Apply area after downgrade.
  * Take control of a standing piece.

If, during play, a piece is moved over and off your opponent's side of the board, place it aside. It is out of play and counts towards your win.

The first player to have a piece of each color cross over and off your opponent’s home row wins.

The object is to win the game by ridding yourself of all cards in your hand before your opponent[s].

Game Summary

Decide on a scorekeeper. Once the cards have been shuffled, the scorekeeper deals 3 cards face down to each player, along with an equal number of white dice, called a stash. The scorekeeper places the remaining cards face down off to one side of the table to form a deck.

The scorekeeper begins the game by rolling two dice (1 black & 1 white) in the center of the table. If no one scores, play rotates clockwise to the next player who rolls two dice. Any two die, including the black die can be rolled (see below). Before each roll players examine their cards to see what dice combinations will be needed to match a card in their hand.

Two white dice from your stash, or. 
One die from your stash, and one (previously rolled) die from the table, or
Two (previously rolled) dice from the table.

Player’s take turns rolling until someone shouts STRUT! indicating a player believes they have won the round. A round is won when you match a card in your hand with a dice combination on the table. Let’s say you have a 4 of a Kind (card) in your hand. There are 8 dice on the table 1,3,4,6 and four 5’s: 5, 5, 5. You quickly shout Strut! believing your dice combination (four 5’s) matches the card (4 of a Kind) in your hand, thus winning the round. But have you? You have if one of your 5’s is the black die. The black die must always be part of the score.

Keeping score is very simple. All dice on the table are scored. The black die counts face value [1]=1 point, [2]= 2 points [3]=3 points, etc. White dice count 1 point each. In the example above, you scored a total of 12 points (5 points for the black die and 7 points for the white dice.)

After each round the winner’s points are totaled by the scorekeeper. After the scorekeeper has recorded the points, the winner discards his/her winning card, placing it “face up” under the deck. If the winner’s accumulated score totals less than 30 points then he/she must draw one new card from the deck. If the winner has accumulated 30 or more points, no card is drawn allowing that player to begin ridding his/her hand of cards in an attempt to win the game. (Re-Action cards are an exception to the “30 points” rule.) All other players keep their cards. Dice on the table are evenly redistributed. Note: As you will see as the game progresses, tactics and strategies become a big part of each round.

The winner begins the next round by rolling 1 black and 1 white die. Play continues until someone shouts Strut! The first player to accumulate 30 or more points with no cards remaining in their hand wins the game.

The Black Rooster

If an opponent throws the Black Rooster card down on your winning card, it spells disaster! You must turn in all the cards in your hand, and draw 3 replacements. Plus, you lose all your accumulated points.

COOPERATION: The Wealth of Nations Game is a boardgame simulating economic systems. It includes four different variants of different skill levels based on different economic systems. BARTER is the beginners' game, MAJORITY RULE is the socialist game, MAKING MONEY is the capitalist game, and AUTONOMY is the expert tournament game.

The game plays up to six players. Each player manages cities. The object of a game is to obtain basic resources for each city while employing the fewest people . Players receive points for each different resource they obtain and bonus points for citizens at leisure.

AUTONOMY simulates a futuristic possible economic system that would produce wealth for everyone with a minimum of work.

The game is based on Information Chain Theory.

In addition to existing as a boardgame, this game is downloadable as an electronic game from the publishers' website.

This card game from 1910 shows pictures of events happening in the suffrage "Votes for Woman" era. I don't know much more about the game except that a copy of it is in The Jon A. Lindseth Suffrage Collection.

The card game had set of 52 cards and features Emmeline Pankhurst and Winston Churchill. The cards are purple, green, and white. The game instructions were included in the box.

You are a politician, and your position in the race depends on your ability to fund raise, advertise, debate and speak to your contingency at the right time and place. Advance your campaign, solidify your position, put yourself in the spotlight as you strategically maneuver around your opponents!

There's foul play on the fairway, as you "revenge" your way to the 19th hole! Designed to bring out the worst in all players! A perfect tee shot can splash in the lake, a sumptuous drive can suddenly be "trampled" in!! It's a question of how craftily you play your "Nasty cards" to impede your opponents. Game can be played on this neat nine-hole course at 2 levels Really, Really Nasty or the slightly less frustrating Relatively Nasty Golf Game. A riot of a game for golf nut or novice alike!

Race to the Fairy Castle is a simple roll and move game from Chad Valley. The object of the game is to reach the Fairy Castle, the ultimate destination for each player,  by getting past dragons, goblins, fiery serpents, wolves and The Black Knight!!

In Banana Split, you want to complete as many ice cream orders as can, especially the valuable banana splits! To set up the game, shuffle the ice cream order deck, then reveal four cards. Shuffle the ingredient deck, and deal each player five cards, which they place behind their screens. On a turn, a player can:


    Draw one card from the ingredient deck.
    Take one ice cream order and play ingredients on it.
    Add one or more ingredient cards to an order already in front of you.


When you play ingredients on an order, you must play exactly as many as are on the card and in the order listed, from top to bottom. When you play the final ingredient on an order, place that card aside as you'll score its point value at the end of the game. Banana split orders can't be built upon turn by turn, but must be claimed all in one go, either by playing all four ingredients at the same time or discarding one wild card ingredient. Special ingredient cards let you steal an ice cream order in progress or take an extra turn.

Once all the ice cream orders have been fulfilled, players tally their scores to see who wins.

This simple roll and move game is probably from the early to the mid 1950's. Game comes with a die, playing pieces and a board with spaces numbered 1 to 120. The board has a couple of detours that might have to be taken on the way to the finish line.

These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the Crimean War period.

Days of Empire is a set of rules for 18mm wargaming. Cavalry and Infantry are represented by stands 50 of men. Artillery, Engineers and Staff are represented by stands of 10 men.  An artillery gun model represents two actual guns.

Each player has a squirrel with a wheelbarrow, trying to get to the island and pick up nuts that match his cards. By rolling a die, players move their squirrels and also the bridges leading to the island. When a squirrel reaches the island, it gets to pick up nuts from the tree. After picking up a maximum of two nuts the squirrel has to run back home to store the nuts. First player to collect five nuts that match his cards wins.

An electronic number generator that comes packaged with sixteen games designed for it. The device has eight light-emitting diodes, numbered one through eight, which flash one at a time. The operator of the device presses a button to freeze the flashing to generate a number. A switch can alter the speed of the flashing to either fast or slow.

These miniatures rules were designed to be both simple and realistic.

Pro Gloria! is a set of rules for 15mm abd 25/28mm wargaming. Cavalry and Infantry are represented by stands 50 of men. Artillery, Engineers and Staff are represented by stands of 10 men. An artillery gun model represents two actual guns.

These miniatures rules were designed specifically for the Franco Prussian War period.

Days of Iron is a set of rules for 15mm wargaming at the regimental scale.  Cavalry and Infantry stands represent 50 men each.  Artillery, Engineers, and Staff stands represent 10 men each.  An artillery gun model represents three actual guns.

Players spin to see what type of plastic brick to add to the wall being built in front of Charlie, who patiently bides his time in the shaft of an elastic-band loaded cannon.  When a certain weight threshold is exceeded, the elastic band trigger is released, propelling Charlie into the wall and eliminating the player who caused this to occur from the game.

The remaining players reset the cannon, replace Charlie & rebuild the wall from scratch, again trying to prevent Charlie from crashing into and collapsing the wall.

The last player remaining is the winner.

From the Press Release:

The high-energy game that combines balancing, jumping, sliding, giggling and more to celebrate your child’s “I Can Do That!” attitude!

The Cat in the Hat has come for a visit and he wants to see all the things that you can do!

Start by flipping over three cards to discover your new challenge. What will it be? Can you jump up and down…while holding the fish…under your chin? Can you limbo under the trick-a-ma-stick…while balancing the boat…on your stomach? If you think you can, shout, “I Can Do That!”

There are hundreds of hilarious possibilities. The player who earns the most stars wins!

The Cat in the Hat – I Can Do That! Game brings to life the beloved Dr. Seuss book giving kids a new and incredibly fun way to experience this classic Dr. Seuss story.

The game of team-work, singing and surprising sleigh-rides!

The Grinch is out to steal the Whos’ gifts—but your family can save the day. Only your singing will warm the Grinch’s heart and bring his sleigh full of stolen gifts speeding down Mt. Crumpit and back to Who-ville!

Collect Who tiles and gifts with each player’s turn. But watch out—draw the wrong tile and the Grinch will steal the gifts back! When that happens, team up with your family or friends: If you sing LONG ENOUGH and LOUD ENOUGH, the Electronic Singing Detector will hear your singing and actually launch the sleigh on its wild ride down Mt. Crumpit! Connect all 12 Who Tiles plus matching gifts, and you win!

All the sheep ran away to the meadow; the players compete with each other to bring back the most sheep to the pen and try to stop the other players from doing the same.
In this fast card game each player tries to get rid of all his cards and especially of the black-sheep card. If that doesn't work, 3 black sheep can win the game!

Currently published only in Hebrew, in Israel.

Thieves have penetrated into building where a unique diamond exhibition is displayed.
Player has to identify those thieves and catch them in the act.
Sharp mind and quick reflexes will help you beat your opponents in this crazy card game.

Players represent the batting and fielding sides in a game of limited overs cricket.
The fielding player sets up his field using white counters to depict his fielders. Counters also represent the batsman and umpires, though these are static.
For each ball in an over, a card is drawn from the deck to represent the outcome of that bowl (no ball, howzat etc.), and the result is recorded in an authentically detailed score book - meaning that at the end of the innings the scores will be represented as in a real match. The positioning of the field affects the likelihood of the batsmen being given out as well as the number of runs they will score.
The box includes: Game board, with all the major fielding positions marked; counters to represent fielders, batsmen and umpires (including several spares); a deck of cards for drawing each ball of the over; An in/out die (green and red sides); A fully authentic cricket score book; four blank cards for replacement/original outcomes.

From the publisher homepage:

MASTER OF TELEVISION
This is the perfect board game about the box! So turn off the telly and turn on the fun in this fast-paced game, where your knowledge of the biggest and the best series of Television are at stake. Stop fighting about the remote control – Fight to become the Master of Television.

Background
THE ULTIMATE TRIVIA GAME FOR EVERYONE WHO LOVES TELEVISION.
In MASTER OF TELEVISION it’s all about how well you know the famous series of the television – You have to know a little about a lot – From "Friends" to "Big Brother". From "McCloud" to "The Eurovision Song Contest", everything can show up on your "screen".
You play to become MASTER OF TELEVISION. The 8 categories cover Drama, Comedy, Shows, even gossip, scandals, strange TV-facts and much much more.
At the very end it comes down to a memorable Quote from a famous TV Series – Who said it and in what series.
MASTER OF TELEVISION is fun, exiting, entertaining and you can never predict how it ends.
MASTER OF TELEVISION can be played by everyone – age is no limitation.

Gameplay
Just like any good night in front of the television MASTER OF TELEVISION entertains from the moment you open the box. You’re ready to play right away, without complicated rules or introductions. You simply play your way through 7 of the 8 categories and when you’ve gathered 7 "Flat Screens", you’re going to face the final question – Recognizing a quote from a TV series and you have to tell your fellow players which TV Quote originated from what TV Series. Then you’ve earned the title MASTER OF TELEVISION.
MASTER OF TELEVISION guarantee you the best TV night without TV.

MASTER OF TELEVISION is the second game in a series of games with the title "Master of….". Next games will be "Master of Music" and "Master of Sports" – More to come…

Quelf Jr. is a game of totally silly nonsensical fun for kids and families!

As you race through the FlapDoodle factory, you’ll use your creativity and imagination to answer crazy questions and do silly stunts. Along the way you might run into to a cranky old man named Mr. SourFace! He’ll try to slow you down. But, if you land on a Ms. Goody Gumdrops space, you’ll get help to move ahead. The first person to make it through the FlapDoodle factory wins, but everyone has fun along the way!

Card example: "Take off your shoes and socks and pretend that your big toes are named Gus and Earl. Make them talk to each other about potato chips."

Reimplements

    Quelf for the younger crowd

Thirty-six tiles numbered one through nine of four colors are dealt to the players. Each player has twelve chips to use to make bids based on which the players will play combination of tiles. As combinations are made, the players receive their rewards. The first player to score a predetermined number of chips is the winner.

From the rulebook: "Revised and expanded to include warfare in The Near East, Egypt and Africa in Old Testament Times.   Includes general orders of battle, tactics, formations, revised casualty calculation method, diagrams, naval & siege rules, Divine Intervention, heroic challenges & Q.R.S.

"Originally published as `Holy Hack: Hacking By the Book Biblical Warfare.'"

This rulebook also features enhanced graphics throughout including color illustrations of examples using photographs of miniatures in play.

For support online, see http://www.classicalhack.com

Avista Pro is a sister game to Avista. Players try to find out a word matching the conditions on cards. First card gives a subject and second card gives initial letter for the word.

Avista Pro uses more difficult subjects than Avista. They are further divided into three difficulty levels: easy, moderate, and difficult.

Avista Pro is really just the 2nd edition of Avista, rather than a self-standing game; the rules are exactly the same, the number of cards is exactly the same, and the first edition already had three difficulty levels; whether the subject matters are more difficult or not is arguable.

In July 1919, General Yudenich was made Commander-in-chief of the Northwestern army of the Whites, and was recognized by Kolchak as his representative. In August, with the aid of England and Esthonia, the Russian “Northwestern Government” was established. Yudenich’s planned Fall offensive was timed to coincide with the pinnacle of the White’s success, as Denikin approached Orel and Tula, the munitions-manufacturing center. From there it was only a short distance to Moscow. Heroic Frenzy covers the battle for Petrograd during this time.

The map scale is about 3-3.5 miles per hex. Each aircraft unit represents one aircraft, each tank unit equals one AFV (armored fighting vehicles), and each armor car unit represents three armor cars. White units are brigades (X), battalions (II). Red units are brigades (X). A game turn represents two days.

The goal of of the game is to let people get acquainted with the new European currency, the Euro. The game is a roll-and-move game with questions and answers and chance, option and assignment cards. You win by getting a complete series of Euro-coins and notes.

This roll-and-move game is set in a Boy Scout camp and the surrounding farmground.  One imagines it was either published in the first half of 1914, before WWI broke out, or had very limited sales. 
Each player starts on his/her own (coloured)route; ending on a marked space follow instructions; first player entering the centre (camp of tents) is the winner.

A racing game were each player has to playing pieces. One is the mechanic that you move around building your car and finding replacement parts as the game goes on. There are many various parts so each player gets his own custom made car, with different abilities ad weaknesses.

The other piece is a sand timer, that is used to represent your car on the race track. On a players turn, he choses whether he wants to move his mechanic or car, but when then sand has run out in the sand timer, the car is out of gas and you need to move the mechanic to refill the car.

The race track has various hazards and shortcut, that may or may not interfere with your car, depending on what custom parts your car is made up of. You might want to move the mechanic around to find you better car parts, but in the end it is the player who first reaches the finish line with his car who wins.

Get onto the island:

Finally, the sun is shining nice and brightly and the swimming pool in the garden is inviting you to enjoy some splashing around. As today was really strenuous, you'd prefer to lie down on your inflatable super cool palm island in the swimming pool, together with your two friends, and just float around. Unfortunately, your other family members have the same idea. But since there's only one air mattress, the turmoil starts right at the edge of the pool. Everyone wants to get to the air mattress first, since he who comes last goes empty handed.

Contents:

1 Game board

1 Die

12 game pieces

Four young gardeners have a communal garden in which each sets out to plant a row of flowers  However, that can be a complicated undertaking; sometimes the bed a gardener chooses is already planted or is reserved for a different color of flower.

Each player chooses a color peg and takes 8 flowers, two of each color.  The players take turns rolling the die and moving their pegs in any direction he chooses but only in one direction.  If a player lands on an un-planted flower bed and has a flower of the same color as the bed, he can plant his flower.  But if the bed is already planted or the player does not have a flower to match the bed, he may not plant a flower.  After a player moves, his turn is over.

The winner is the first play to plant all his flowers.

Swedish game for children.

The dogs take on the cats in the back alleys. One player takes control of the dogs (six of them), the other the cats (equal amount). The players then take turns rolling the dice, moving their animals across the board. If your animal finishes its move on top of one of the opponent's you have won that fight and the loser is removed from play.

Whoever gets his animals knocked out first loses.

Two to four players compete for Electoral votes, based on their knowledge of U.S. state capitols and their luck with a spinner. Starting with the player who has the spinner, the player who correctly guesses the state associated with a given capitol city gets to mark the state with his peg. When all states are claimed, the player with the most Electoral votes (as determined by the 1927 map board) is the winner.

At the time of this game, red was the color of the Democratic party and blue was that of the Republicans (vs. the current Republican=red state, Democrat=blue state association). For the third and fourth players, the Independent (yellow) and the Prohibition (natural) parties are also included.

This game was later sold, with minor cosmetic modifications, as E. E. Fairchild Corp.'s Battle of Ballots. The only major difference is that this version uses a spinner to randomly select capital cities, while the later version uses a deck of cards.

Similar to Jungle, the forerunner of Stratego.

Each player has 13 animals, with strengths ranging from 1 to 13. The players move their animals orthogonally one space per turn and compare strengths between animals when one moves into an occupied space. The higher strength wins and captures the other animal, except in the case of the mouse (strength 1) which can capture an elephant (strength 13).

There is a set of variant cards with the game which will offer some variety to the game by granting powers.

The goal of the game is to push or pull an opponent's piece so that it lands in the central hole.

Players do not choose which pieces to move, they play in a fixed order. However, rings can be placed on the pieces to give them special move alternatives like jumping and picking up other pieces.

Race your ants along a path while avoiding grasshoppers, Molt and Thumper.  Use grasshoppers to block your opponents.
Be the first to reach the end and topple Hopper.
It appears to be a roll and move game with other features.
Slask 1939 (Silesia 1939) depicts the battle taking part in southwestern Poland during the 1939 invasion.
